questions.explanation:

Psoriatic arthritis The patient’s clinical picture is considered the classic presentation for psoriatic arthritis. It is a seronegative inflammatory arthritis associated with characteristic nail changes (pitting and transverse ridges). The other answers do not apply to the constellation of findings.

questions.text: Sacroiliac joint involvement in ankylosing spondylitis may be elicited by which of the following clinical signs?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both of the above Bilateral compression of the pelvis and Gaenslen’s test are important clinniocal signs for demonstration of Ankylosing Spondylitis Tests for detecting sacroiliac involvement: Sacro-iliac compression: Direct side-to-side compression of the pelvis may cause pain at the sacroiliac joints. Gaenslen's test : The opposite side's hip and knee joints are flexed to fix the pelvis and the hip joint of the side under the test is hyperextended over the table's edge . This will exert a rotational strain over the sacroiliac joint and give rise to pain Straight leg raising test : The patient is asked to lift the leg up with the knee extended . This will cause pain in the affected sacroiliac joint. Pump-handle tes t: With the patient lying supine, the examiner flexes his hip and knee completely and forces the affected knee across the chest to bring it close to the opposite shoulder. This will cause pain on the affected side .

questions.text: Which of the following has been classically described as podagra?

options.label: A
options.text: Deposits of urate at the pinna

options.label: B
options.text: Acute inflammation of the first metatarsophalangeal joint

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute inflammation of the first metatarsophalangeal joint
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute inflammation of the first metatarsophalangeal joint Swelling, redness, heat and exquisite tenderness of the MTP joint of the great toe (‘podagra’) is the epitome of gout .

Highyeild:

Gout is a disorder of purine metabolism characterised by hyperuricaemia, deposition of monosodium urate monohydrate crystals in joints and per-articular tissues and recurrent attacks of acute synovitis. Clinical Features of Gout Clinical Feature The stereotype patient is an obese, hypertensive male and fond of alcohol An acute attack is a sudden onset of severe joint pain that lasts for a week or two, and usually comes out of the blue but may be precipitated by minor trauma, illness, unaccustomed exercise or alcohol, steroid withdrawal, hypouricemic therapy, MI, stroke The commonest sites are the metatarsophalangeal joint of the big toe > ankle & finger joints and olecranon bursae. The skin is red, shiny, swollen, hot and extremely tender, suggesting cellulitis or septic arthritis. Characteristic negatively birefringent urate crystals in the synovial fluid examined by polarising microscopy is diagnostic. During the acute gouty attack, strongly birefringent needle and rod-shaped monosodium urate (MSU) crystals with negative elongation are largely intracellular. During an acute attack, x-rays show only soft tissue swelling. Chronic gout may result in joint space narrowing & secondary OA Tophi appearing as characteristic punched-out cysts or deep erosions with overhanging bony edges (Martel's or G' sign). These well-defined erosions are larger & slightly further from the joint margin than typical RA erosions.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed to have rheumatoid arthritis 2 years back. This patient has been planned to undergo total hip replacement and is currently taking methotrexate. What should be done with respect to methotrexate administration?

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced to half the dose but not stopped

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continued as usual Although there is a higher rate of infection in general in rheumatoid patients, continuing their methotrexate at the normal dose has not been shown to affect their risk of infection. Conversely, discontinuing their methotrexate may result in a disease flare that impedes their post-operative rehabilitation.

Highyeild:

Treatment of RA Drugs used: NSAIDS: To control the symptoms and signs of the local inflammatory process. These drugs have minimal effect on the progression of the disease. Disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARD) Methotrexate b. Hydroxychloroquine Sulfasalazine d. Penicillamine Gold f. Glucocorticoid therapy Newer advancements in the management of RA Anti TNF alpha drugs like Infliximab, adalimumab IL-1 Receptor antagonist anakinra Anti CD20 antibody rituximab Immunosuppressive drugs like azathioprine, leflunomide, cyclosporine, and cyclophosphamide. Surgery-Synovectomy, joint debridement or joint replacements can be done depending upon the destruction of the joint.
